authority.name: A.B.E. — Doctrine Map
authority.description: Structured map of constitutional, judge-made, and ultra-vires doctrines for use across CDA, CFF, CIRI, and law modules.

void_ab_initio_criteria: Removes or nullifies a guaranteed remedy
Transfers power from the people to the government without amendment
Creates a penalty for exercising a right
Invents power not delegated in the Constitution

categories.name: Constitutional Core
categories.description: Doctrines that arise directly from constitutional text and are text-aligned implementations.

categories.name: Judge-Made, Text-Aligned
categories.description: Judicial doctrines created for administrability that are legitimate when applied in a way consistent with constitutional text.

categories.name: Judge-Made, Ultra Vires / Text-Conflicting
categories.description: Doctrines that have no clear textual basis and conflict with structure, rights, or remedies.

categories.name: Driver Licensing & Enforcement Overreach
categories.description: Doctrines and practices that bridge commercial law into non-commercial citizens and transportation policing.

categories.name: Modern Corrective Shifts
categories.description: Recent doctrinal shifts (e.g., Major Questions, Nondelegation revival) that narrow agency power and reinforce A.B.E.'s alignment claims.

doctrines.name: Judicial Review
doctrines.source: Marbury v. Madison (1803); Article III; Supremacy Clause
doctrines.text_basis: Courts must decide cases under the law; the Constitution and laws made under it are supreme.
uses: Confirms courts have a duty to strike down unconstitutional statutes, doctrines, and practices.
Supports A.B.E.'s insistence that ultra-vires doctrines are not binding simply because they are old.

doctrines.name: Supremacy Clause Doctrine
doctrines.source: U.S. Const. art. VI
doctrines.text_basis: The Constitution and laws of the United States made in pursuance thereof are the supreme law of the land.
uses: Federal commercial limits and funding conditions override conflicting state practices.
Underpins A.B.E. arguments about FMCSA/MCSAP scope and state overreach.

doctrines.name: Incorporation Doctrine
doctrines.source: Fourteenth Amendment, Due Process; key cases like Gitlow, McDonald
doctrines.text_basis: States must respect fundamental rights enumerated in the Bill of Rights.
uses: Brings Fourth, Fifth, and Fourteenth protections to state traffic, CPS, and credit practices.
Restricts 'police power' narratives that ignore federal rights.

doctrines.name: Equal Protection Doctrine
doctrines.source: Fourteenth Amendment, Equal Protection Clause
doctrines.text_basis: No state shall deny to any person the equal protection of the laws.
uses: Supports challenges to selective traffic enforcement and discriminatory licensing.
Helps flag unequal treatment in CPS, credit underwriting, and mobility access.

doctrines.name: Void for Vagueness / Overbreadth
doctrines.source: Due Process; numerous Supreme Court decisions
doctrines.text_basis: Laws must be clear enough that ordinary people can understand what is prohibited and not invite arbitrary enforcement.
uses: Applied to vague traffic, CPS, and licensing statutes that invite open-ended discretion.
Supports A.B.E. arguments that citizens cannot be punished under incoherent or overbroad codes.

doctrines.name: Levels of Scrutiny
doctrines.source: Judge-made tiers (strict, intermediate, rational basis)
doctrines.text_basis: Not in text; tool courts use to weigh burdens on rights.
uses: Helps show that when travel and liberty are properly recognized, licensing burdens cannot hide under 'rational basis'.
Used to test whether safety claims match actual commercial nexus and evidence.

doctrines.name: Standing / Ripeness / Mootness
doctrines.source: Article III case-or-controversy gloss
doctrines.text_basis: Courts may only decide real disputes, not hypotheticals.
uses: Recognizes that access filters exist but rejects their use to dodge ongoing rights violations.
Supports A.B.E. framing that systemic harms (e.g., funding misuse) are live controversies.

doctrines.name: Exclusionary Rule
doctrines.source: Fourth Amendment remedy doctrine (e.g., Mapp v. Ohio)
doctrines.text_basis: Evidence obtained in violation of the Fourth Amendment is inadmissible.
uses: Supports suppression when traffic stops, searches, and seizures begin in ultra-vires enforcement.
Aligns with A.B.E.'s view that unlawful processes cannot generate lawful outcomes.

doctrines.name: Federalism Balancing Doctrines
doctrines.source: Anti-commandeering, intergovernmental immunity, etc.
doctrines.text_basis: Structural inferences from Articles I, II, III and Tenth Amendment.
uses: Helps show that states may not convert federal commercial regimes into universal citizen control.
Helps expose when 'compliance' with federal law is actually overreach beyond federal scope.

doctrines.name: Police Power Doctrine
doctrines.source: 19th–20th century state case law; not grounded in constitutional text.
doctrines.text_basis: No explicit grant of inherent police powers in the federal Constitution.
uses: Shows that 'police power' claims cannot override explicit constitutional rights and limits.
Provides grounding to attack state claims of inherent authority to license all movement or life activity.

doctrines.name: Qualified Immunity
doctrines.source: Harlow v. Fitzgerald and progeny
doctrines.text_basis: Not present in §1983 text or the Constitution.
uses: Demonstrates that courts carved out protections for officials that the text does not grant.
Supports A.B.E. remedies arguments that rights must have real, accessible enforcement pathways.

doctrines.name: Expanded Sovereign Immunity (Eleventh Amendment doctrine)
doctrines.source: Post–Eleventh Amendment case law expanding immunity beyond text.
doctrines.text_basis: Eleventh Amendment text is narrow; later doctrine is much broader.
uses: Shows where state immunity has been expanded beyond what the text supports.
Connects to A.B.E.'s focus on access to remedies and accountability for unlawful funding/enforcement.

doctrines.name: Community Caretaking Doctrine
doctrines.source: Earlier lower court cases; narrowed in Caniglia v. Strom (2021)
doctrines.text_basis: Judge-made; stretches beyond traditional warrant exceptions.
uses: Used to argue that generic 'safety' cannot justify warrantless home intrusions or traffic intrusions without RAS.
Supports attacks on non-specific, pretextual traffic stops.

doctrines.name: Special Needs Doctrine
doctrines.source: Cases allowing suspicionless searches for 'special needs'
doctrines.text_basis: Not explicit in text; carves out new category of searches.
uses: Highlights that general policing of non-commercial drivers does not fit true 'special needs'.
Undercuts suspicionless checkpoints and chemical tests used as routine policing tools.

doctrines.name: Automobile Exception Expansion
doctrines.source: Carroll and its progeny
doctrines.text_basis: Originally narrow; expanded significantly over time.
uses: Shows how mobility became the wedge for deep intrusions into privacy.
Supports A.B.E.’s structural argument that traffic policing has been leveraged far beyond commerce-related safety.

doctrines.name: Commerce Clause Misuse for Universal Licensing
doctrines.source: Commerce Clause; misapplied by states and agencies
doctrines.text_basis: Commerce power is about regulating interstate commerce, not private non-commercial travel.
uses: Demonstrates how commercial authority was used as a pretext to license all adult movement.
Supports A.B.E.'s distinction between commercial drivers and non-commercial citizens.

doctrines.name: FMCSR Adoption Doctrine (49 CFR 300–399, 350)
doctrines.source: 49 CFR 350.303; 49 CFR 390.3; FMCSA/MCSAP conditions
doctrines.text_basis: States may adopt FMCSRs for commercial motor vehicle safety; scope is limited to defined commercial activity.
uses: Links MCSAP and FMCSA funding conditions to lawful scope (commercial only).
Shows that applying FMCSRs to private, non-commercial drivers is outside authorized scope and funding terms.

doctrines.name: Implied Consent for Non-Commercial Drivers
doctrines.source: State statutes and case law extending implied consent doctrines
doctrines.text_basis: Not grounded in Fourth/Fifth Amendment text; conflicts with consent principles and DOT Part 40.
uses: Shows that 'consent' extracted under threat of license loss or arrest is not true consent.
Ties directly into A.B.E.'s right-to-travel and bodily integrity arguments.

doctrines.name: Administrative Deference (Chevron / Auer-style)
doctrines.source: Chevron, Auer, and related cases (partly limited in recent decisions)
doctrines.text_basis: Courts historically deferred heavily to agency interpretations.
uses: Recent limitations help courts scrutinize DOT and state interpretations of scope.
Strengthens A.B.E.'s claim that agencies cannot invent new classes of regulated people by 'interpretation'.

doctrines.name: Major Questions Doctrine
doctrines.source: Recent Supreme Court cases (e.g., West Virginia v. EPA)
doctrines.text_basis: Agencies need clear congressional authorization for decisions of vast economic and political significance.
uses: Supports the argument that DOT and states lack clear authority to convert non-commercial travel into a licensed, quasi-criminal regime.
Backs A.B.E.'s view that large-scale economic and civil-liberty impacts require explicit legislative authorization.

doctrines.name: Nondelegation Revival
doctrines.source: Emerging Supreme Court skepticism of broad delegations
doctrines.text_basis: Article I vests legislative power in Congress; agencies and states cannot assume vague open-ended power.
uses: Highlights that neither Congress nor agencies clearly delegated power to license mere existence in public space.
Supports A.B.E.'s thesis that licensing + traffic enforcement overreach sit in a nondelegation gap.
